rev.comment: Lacks additional independant references. Too few countries to support worldwide view of necrophilia, e.g. where on some places it would be acceptable(?)

'''Necrophilia''', also called '''thanatophilia''' and '''necrolagnia''', is the [[human sexuality|sexual]] attraction to corpses. It is classified as a [[paraphilia]] by the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual]] of the [[American Psychiatric Association]]. The word is artificially derived from Ancient Greek: ''[[wikt:Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ|Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ]]'' (''nekros''; "corpse," or "dead") and ''[[wikt:ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±|ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±]]'' (''philia''; "love"). The term appears<ref name="litera">{{ru icon}} [http://www.netslova.ru/gorny/necro.html "ÐÐÐÐ ÐÐ¤ÐÐÐÐ¯ ÐÐÐ Ð¡Ð¢Ð Ð£ÐÐ¢Ð£Ð Ð Ð¡ÐÐÐÐÐÐÐ¯"], 2002.</ref> to have originated from [[Richard Freiherr von Krafft-Ebing|Krafft-Ebing]]'s 1886 work ''[[Psychopathia Sexualis (book)|Psychopathia Sexualis]]''.<ref>Krafft-Ebing, Richard von (1886). ''Psychopathia Sexualis''. English translation: ISBN 1-55970-425-X.</ref>
'''Necrophilia''', also called '''thanatophilia''' and '''necrolagnia''', is the [[human sexuality|sexual]] attraction to corpses. It is classified as a [[paraphilia]] by the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual]] of the [[American Psychiatric Association]]. The word is artificially derived from Ancient Greek: ''[[wikt:Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ|Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ]]'' (''nekros''; "corpse," or "dead") and ''[[wikt:ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±|ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±]]'' (''philia''; "love"). ''Psychopathia Sexualis''. English translation: ISBN 1-55970-425-X.</ref>
